comments.commentBody: It is the 12th shot, black and empty, that speaks the most volumes.
To borrow a phrase from the Teasel Party, I had to "man up" for this one!  A fine debut, I thought.  I'm too tired to think anymore...  Hope everyone had a delightful day.

Jim, it's been great interacting with you over the years. I'll look forward to seeing you at the ACPT, and I truly hope you keep xwordinfo up and running -- it's a great resource!

I've done many things in my life, and one of the things that sets the crossword community apart is that it brings together an enormously varied group of smart, classy people. Jim, you're absolutely representative of that mix. Thanks for being part of the community -- and for, I trust, staying part of it -- blog or no!

Dear Jim,
I have been doing crossword puzzles for nearly fifty years. Your Wordplay blog opened a new dimension of what had been a mostly solitary activity. I am deeply grateful for your wit and insight, and for allowing me to meet and participate in a community of like-minded puzzlers, who are knowledgeable, funny, and who get ninety percent of my puns. I join their voices in wishing you the very best.

Visiting the blog has come to be as enjoyable to me as doing the puzzles.  Sometimes quite a bit more enjoyable, actually!  But my skills are slowly improving, since I'm compelled to do the puzzle every day (or try, anyhow) so I can get to the blog.  Thanks so much for your clever and enlightening commentary.  It's been a pleasure to read!

Well, I'm very impressed that so many of you found the time to write anything yesterday. I was cooking from 5:30 AM till about thirty of us sat down to eat at 4.
I didn't get to see the Saturday puzzle until 9pm. I want to wish you all a joyous holiday season, and now that the solstice is past, may each of your days be filled with returning light. Having said that, here's a link to Tom Lehrer's Christmas Carol – one of my favorites.
http://www.youtube.com...

I liked seeing moiety and epact, but then, I liked seeing andromeda on Friday.

Ah, but if only politicians were more like artists: generous (typically), curious, open to learning and experience, respectful (usually) of one another even when they might deem the other's work relatively trivial. Of course perhaps these differences better explain why art matters so little in the US, while politics, as we brace ourselves on a daily basis for the next outrage or atrocity, always matters too much.
What a remarkable column about a remarkable book (and author). Well done, and thanks.

Could anyone imagine Smith and Mapplethorpe running into one another in today's sanitized, suburbanized high income theme park that is today's Manhattan?

Thirty years of unbridled real estate speculation has eliminated our coastal cultural crucibles, hothouses which fomented American culture, marginalized in the day, that stands the tests of time as classics.
First time your column has me in tears. Love and friendship has no bounds.
Maureen:  I frequently disagree with your opinions and outlook but this was a nice piece for a snowy Christmas evening.  No judgements, just obsevations on an interesting person.  Thanks.

Absolute right. A beautifully written, evocative love story that brigs to life an era, an artist and a love affair. Smith writes honestly, but is not confession; her book is an operetta, a poem, an experience. You will be transported not merely into another time, but into an artistic consciousness -- the one created by the union of Smith and Mapplethorpe. Patty Smith is a wholly original creative force who transcends disciplinary boundaries -- she's a poet, a musician, a nonfiction writer -- to make something that is part poem, part non-fiction, and part operetta. You will finish this book and say, "What exactly was that; it was wonderful?" A true artist follows no rules; she makes it new.

Brava, Maureen, for writing this column. Everyone else -- no kidding -- read this book.
just one word: Beautiful

True, so true.
ARTISTS these days
are merely artists.

"It unfolds in that romantic time before we were swallowed by Facebook, flat screens, texts, tweets and Starbucks; when people still talked all night and listened to jukeboxes and LPs and read actual books and drank black coffee." I think you have stumbled upon what might be a worthy resolution for the coming New Year--namely to be unswallowed by Facebook etc and start talking to each all night and read actual books and listen to LP's...

Great article. I'm currently reading Just Kids and am very moved by it. What a beautiful love story. Wouldn't it be wonderful if everyone had such a great love as Patti and Robert had? I'd give anything to have  that in my life.
It's always nice when anyone discovers the heartache and truth of opera.  Your recent columns tell me that you have arrived at this place of magical beauty.  Welcome!
maureen,this is the kind of stuff that gives liberals a bad name.

I just finished reading Patti Smith's beautiful memoir as well. It certainly made me nostalgic for a more innocent time in New York, in the world. And I know it sounds corny, but their love story actually brought me to tears.
A beautiful story. Thank you.
Beautifully written!

Maureen, for a change I don't have one word of criticism, only praise for your thoughtfull essay.
Thanks.
Glenn Gould and Hendrix. I'll have something to talk about if I ever meet her.
Beautiful

Thank you, Frank, for once again laying out the big picture and putting our newfound smallness in historical perspective. The fact is that we Americans are busy making ourselves small. Who killed the Disneyland dream? We did.

The main problem is that we have become a small-minded, selfish people. Instead of pulling together for progress, we have all becomes members of narrow special interest groups: greedy geezers, anti-choice, pro-choice, immigration reformers, border defenders, gay rights advocates, defenders of "traditional" marriage, militarists, corporatists, unions, anti-unionists, corn farmers, environmentalists, mountain-top strippers, loggers, home-schoolers, religious fundamentalists, non-theists, "real" Americans, intelligentsia. We are now defined by niche greed.

None of us wants to pay for anybody else's niche. Too bad if you're poor. Sorry you're sick. Out of work? Losing your job? Want better schools? Well, those aren't MY problems.

The tax-reduction mantra, and the tax-cut law the President so proudly rammed through Congress, are symptomatic of a great American pathology. Any half-sensible person can see that tax cuts are a sure path to the defeat of the American dream. In the halcyon days of the 1950s, when the Barstow family believed (with good reason) that anything was possible, federal tax rates were nearly twice what they are now, although they were decidedly more progressive; that is, the rich paid a larger share. And the rich were not as rich. Income inequality was exponentially smaller than it is today. The Barstows' dreams were not delusional; they were possible. Not any more.

In the last election, we voted out the only hope for a better American future. Admittedly, it was mostly hope, and not a lot of change. The cartoonist Darrin Bell perhaps put it best: "We're angry nothing's changed so we vote for those who've spent two years blocking change. Is America the only country that votes sarcastically?" Bell asks.

We have a President and Congress who revel in & depend upon the status quo. I don't care what they say they believe in; I've been watching what they do. Not much. We have a large percentage of the populace who likes it that way, too. Every social or public program that doesn't directly benefit ME is "socialism." Like the politicians, the American people say they want change, but the change many want is to return, not to the hopeful 1950s, but to the oppressive 1780s. These voters are not merely catatonic; they are regressive.

Because of the intense interest over the past two years in a Congress that was proposing grand things but doing almost nothing to change the status quo, Americans saw Washington -- and the Max Baucus/Mitch McConnell Senate in particular -- for what it is: a body that is broken, a legislative body that purposely does not legislate.

Now we are about to watch a new Congress that will be even more dysfunctional. However the Senate tinkers with the filibuster rules, it still won't do much. Besides, with a small Democratic majority in the upper chamber and a solid Republican majority in the House, it would be foolhearty to expect any progress. At all.

We are doomed by the choices we have made. Congress is abominable. The President is either a fool or a charlatan. But we narrow-minded, greedy, shortsighted citizens got the government most of us deserve.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com
